There are multiple types of actors, some of which are designed to be used for characters and creatures within the game world whilst others are meta objects to be used as templates.

Travellers, NPCs, Creatures and Packages are considered to be 'characters'. Spacecraft (and Vehicles and Starports once support is added) are considered a different type of Actor, and how Items are treated when added to them can be different.

Character Types

Traveller

Travellers represent player characters.

  • Full list of characteristics

  • Full list of skills

  • Damage is applied to characteristics

  • Equipment can be assigned

  • Has a full career history

A Traveller will be given a random space man icon on creation.

NPC

NPCs are simplified versions of Travellers, designed to be used for less important characters.

  • Full list of characteristics

  • Full list of skills

  • Damage is applied to a unified HITS total

An NPC will be given a random space man icon on creation.

Creature

Creatures represent animals which lack human intelligence.

  • Have no characteristics

  • Have a limited set of skills

  • Damage is applied to a unified HITS total

A Creature will be given a random Creature icon on creation.

Package

A package is a template that can be applied to a Traveller or NPC. They can be used to define simplified career packages (such as those found in the Traveller Companion), or used to set up custom packages of skills to quickly build up NPCs. Dragging a Package on top of a Traveller or NPC character sheet will copy skills, items and other attributes onto the destination character.

A Package is given a grey space man icon on creation.

It is recommended that a Career Term is given to a package. This will be copied to the destination Traveller or NPC and provide a record of which packages have been used.

Characteristics are specified as modifiers (-1 / 0 / +2 etc), and will modify the UPP of the destination character.

If the Racial Package option is ticked, than rather than applying modifiers to existing characteristics, completely new characteristics will be rolled when the package is applied. It defaults to using 2D6, but other values for non-humans can be specified. These support the full range of Foundry dice options, so it is possible to specify 3D6k2 for more 'heroic' characteristics, or 3D6kl2 for lower values.

Height and Weight

If the package has non-zero height and weight set, then a random height and weight will be automatically set on the target actor modified by physical characteristics. This can be changed afterwards by the player, and should only be used as a very rough suggestion. Mostly it is so that NPCs don't all have the same boring default values.

Weight is modified upwards by STR and END, downwards by DEX.

Height is modified upwards by STR.

If the actor's gender is set to Male, then both are modified upwards. If they are defined as Female, then height and weight are modified downwards. Other values in the gender field have no effect.

Spacecraft

Spacecraft Tokens

A number of tokens are available for some of the most common spaceships in Traveller. Each is available in a range of different colours.

If you want to use them as actual tokens, the size of each token is scaled according to the size of the ship.

The smallest ship are designed for use as 1x1 tokens, 30t or larger are 2x2, 100t or larger are 3x3 and 300t or larger are 4x4.

Spacecraft represent both smallcraft and starships. Their character sheet is design to represent a space craft, and it has several panels for different types of items:

  • The Ship's Locker contains typical Traveller equipment, including weapons and armour.

  • The Cargo Hold contains anything which is 'Cargo'.

  • Hardware contains actual ship's hardware, such as jump drives, turrets, power plants and the like.

Cargo and Hardware need to be created as standalone items before they can be added to a Spacecraft.

Crew Roles

Crew, in the form of Travellers and NPCs, can be added to the ship by dragging their actor to it. This will initially be added as Passengers, but can be promoted to crew by clicking the icon on their card.

Clicking on a crew or passenger's portrait will open their full character sheet. Otherwise you can click the edit button to assign them to roles aboard the ship. Roles have to be first added to the ship, by dragging a 'Crew Role' item to it.

A role can define a number of actions that crew members with that role can perform.

@UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.traveller-docs.JournalEntry.XqtcLHYC383iXuNo.JournalEntryPage.M6w2juT3bwCbEXdU#creating-a-role]{Creating a Role}

Weapons

Weapon items which have a scale of 'Starship' are added to a spacecraft as potential weapon systems rather than put in the ship's locker. They can then assigned to weapon mounts which are defined by Starship Hardware.

@UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.traveller-docs.JournalEntry.XqtcLHYC383iXuNo.JournalEntryPage.qLZ9BdVEeSIbwc57]{Spacecraft Weapons}

Spacecraft are currently partially supported, so not all features are complete.

Creating A Character

When a new character is created, you are presented with a basic character sheet, which will look something like the following. If you are creating an NPC, the character will be slightly different, but the overall is the same.

The standard six characteristics are displayed near the top, along with a Roll Characteristics icon. Clicking this will roll 2D6 for each of your characteristics. You can click this to re-roll if you want, plus you can drag the characteristic values around to swap them over. Once you have the characteristics you want (or the GM tells you to stop re-rolling), you can disable the button by ticking the 'Lock UPP' option under Settings.

If you shift-click the roll button, then you will get a more average set of characteristics. If you ctrl-click it, then the current characteristics will be varied slightly. These two options are mostly of use for NPCs.

Modifying your characteristics in these ways will output the changes to the chat.

The Damage Stats box allows you to control which characteristics can take damage. Click the cog icon to select or deselect your options. The three core physical characteristics of STR, DEX and END will always be displayed for Travellers.

The Sheet Tabs allow you to choose which details you want to display.

  • Skills - The default, shows your characters' skills, and allows you to roll and modify them.

  • Equipment - What you are carrying, wearing or own.

  • Finance - Financial information about your character.

  • Biography - A place to write a description of your character, plus some background details.

  • History - A place to record what the character did during their life path process.

  • Settings - General settings for the character.

The Skill Filters options allow you to hide skills. Trained only will display only skills you are trained in. Background will just display the background skill options which are taken at the start of character generation.

The Skills tab lists all the skills available to you. Some skills are only displayed if certain characteristics are enabled. For example, the Psionic talents are hidden unless the PSI characteristic is enabled.

Characteristics

Travellers and NPCs start with six basic characteristics, known as their Universal Personality Profile (UPP). These consist of:

  • STRength

  • DEXterity

  • ENDurance

  • INTellect

  • EDUcation

  • SOCial Class

They all default to 7, and are rolled on 2D6, giving a normal range between 2 and 12.

Adding Characteristics

If you go to the Settings tab on the character sheet, you can enable or disable characteristics for your character. Optional ones, such as LUC (Luck), STY (Sanity) and CHA (Charisma) are available to choose from. If these are enabled, then they will be displayed along side the basic characteristics.

If you have more than 6 characteristics, you might want to change how many columns characterstics are displayed in.

Damaging Characteristics

NPCs

NPCs take damage to a generic HITs score. This defaults to the sum of STR, DEX and END. There is an 'Auto HITs

' option in the Settings tab which will allow you to specify a different maximum Hits for an NPC.

Travellers

Travellers take damage to individual characteristics. This is normally applied to STR, DEX and END.

Generating Characteristics

There are a couple of quick ways to roll characteristics for a new character.

  • Type /upp in the chat and drag the results to your character sheet,

  • Click the dice symbol on the top right of the characteristics on the sheet.

    • Shift-clik the dice symbol to roll a set of average characteristics.

    • Ctrl-click the dice symbol to modify existing characteristics between -2 and +2.

Under the settings tab, there is an option to lock your characteristics, This removes the dice symbol and makes it harder to accidentally change your characteristics.

Skills

A skill can be rolled by clicking the skill on the character sheet. This will bring up a dialog that allows you to select which characteristic to use, set a difficulty and add a Dice Modifier.

Each skill has a default characteristics, but you can change this every time that you make a roll. If you tick the "Remember Characteristic" box, then your choice will be remembered for next time for this character.

You can choose a roll type of "Normal", "Boon" or "Bane".

You can also set the difficulty to be something other than the default of 8. It also allows you to give yourself a bonus or penalty to the roll by setting the DM.

Editing Skills

If you are rolling a skill from the character itself, rather than from a token, then there will be an "Edit Skill" option. This can be used to edit the skill. Either change its name, or set whether it is a combat skill or background skill. You can also delete the skill from here.

If you are rolling a skill from a token which doesn't have Link Actor option set, then the edit option will not be available.

Quick Rolls

Holding shift when clicking a skill will perform a quick roll, which skips the dialog and assumes defaults on everything.

The configurable Default to Quick Rolls can be used to reverse this behaviour. If selected, clicking a skill with perform a roll with default settings, and holding shift will open the dialog.

Experience

Holding Ctrl when clicking on a skill will open the experience menu for this skill. This allows you to:

  • Add experience points to the skill. These will automatically increase the skill when the dialog is closed if the experience is enough.

  • Add a permanent DM bonus to the skill. This is useful for racial bonuses.

When you submit the dialog, it will calculate whether you have enough experience to level up, and automatically level up that skill.

A skill with extra experience on it as a + symbol next to it on the character sheet.

Hot bar

Skills can be dragged to the hot bar. Clicking (or shift clicking) on the hot bar icon will roll that skill for the currently selected token.

Travellers and NPCs start with six basic characteristics, known as their Universal Personality Profile (UPP). These consist of:

  • STRength

  • DEXterity

  • ENDurance

  • INTellect

  • EDUcation

  • SOCial Class

They all default to 7, and are rolled on 2D6, giving a normal range between 2 and 12.

Adding Characteristics

If you go to the Settings tab on the character sheet, you can enable or disable characteristics for your character. Optional ones, such as LUC, STY and CHA are available to choose from.

Generating Characteristics

There are a couple of quick ways to roll characteristics for a new character.

  • Type /upp in the chat and drag the results to your character sheet,

  • Click the dice symbol on the top right of the characteristics on the sheet.

    • Shift-clik the dice symbol to roll a set of average characteristics.

    • Ctrl-click the dice symbol to modify existing characteristics between -2 and +2.

Under the settings tab, there is an option to lock your characteristics, This removes the dice symbol and makes it harder to accidentally change your characteristics.

The following features on a character sheet may not be immediately obvious, so are highlighted below.

  • Shift click on a skill or attack to roll it immediately without a dialog. Under system settings, the default (quick roll, or dialog) can be switched.

  • Ctrl click on a skill to open a dialog to display and set XP spent on a skill, or set species level bonuses.

  • Skills can be dragged to the hotbar.

  • When a top level skill is rolled, if it has any specialities with a score greater than one, then the total will be displayed for all these specialities as well as the top level skill.

The system has a built-in random NPC generator. By default, it is used to randomly generate passengers. However, it can be used separately, and can be extended.

The bulk of the work is done via RollTables, which are looked for in the NPC Generator folder. Only tables in this folder are used, though other folders can be passed if a different set of configuration options is wanted.

There are a number of tables required, and they need to follow a certain pattern.

Species

The first table is "Species", This contains a list of species names, which are also used to find the next set of tables.

Results could be as simple as:

  • Human

  • Aslan

  • Vargr

The species name is added to the NPC sheet, and then used to look for the following tables:

Gender

The next table is Gender <Species>, and if that is not found, simply Gender.

It will normally consist of two options, Male and Female. However, it can be extended to include any number of options. It can also be used to set the frequency of each gender.

Name

The Name table is used to randomly generate a name for the NPC. There will a table for each Species, possibly split by Gender. For example:

  • Name Human Male

  • Name Human Female

  • Name Bwap

Humans have two tables, one for Male names and one for Female names.

Bwaps have a single table.

The entries in these tables can be a simple list of names. However, they will often be more complicated than that, and refer to sub-tables.

An entry for the Name Human Male table might be:

  • !Name_Human_First_Male !Name_Human_Family

The ! at the start of a word means go off an find a table of that name (underscores are replaced with spaces) and replace the table name with the result of the second table.

So for this example, a random human male first name would be chosen, followed by a random human surname.

Profession

Finally, the profession table is rolled to check the profession of the NPC. This may be a single table, but will be searched in the following order:

  • Profession <species> <passage>

  • Profession <species>

  • Profession <passage>

  • Profression

Each species can have its own profession table, plus each level of passage (low, basic, middle and high) can each have their own professions table as well.

Using the Tables

These tables are automatically used when a random passenger is dragged onto a spacecraft from a world. An NPC will be created, and placed in the NPC Passengers folder for Actors. When the passenger disembarks, the NPC will be deleted if it is still in this folder.

If the NPC is removed out of the folder, then it will not be deleted. This allows some NPCs to be kept for later use if they turn out to be memorable.

Scripted Used

It is also possible to use these tables from a macro using the following code:

let text = await game.mgt2e.generateText("Profession")

The argument to generateText is the name of the table to use.

Creating an NPC

It is also possible to generate an NPC with the generateNpc() method.

let npcData = {
    type: "npc",
    name: "Unnamed",
    img: `systems/mgt2e/icons/actors/traveller-red.svg`,
    system: {
        settings: {
        hideUntrained: true,
        lockCharacteristis: true
    },
    sophont: {
        age: await roll("16 + 2D6"),
        homeworld: worldActor.name
    }
}

game.mgt2e.generateNpc(npcData);
Actor.create(npcData);

Advanced Options

When calling `generateText()`, certain text commands can be inserted into the contents of the roll tables. The text is split into words, and words beginning with a special character will be treated specially.

!TableName

Finds the table named, and replaces this word with the results of that table.

$TableName

As for !TableName, but any whitespace is removed from the results.

$^TableName

As for $TableName, but the first letter is capitalised.

[STR+1] or [admin+1]

Increment characteristic or skill by the given amount. This only applies when calling generateNpc, and modifies the npcData block. Some special fields are also supported. For now, `age` is the only one.

Note that if a skill with specialities is chosen, then a random speciality will be incremented. If you want to modify a specific speciality, use <skill>.<speciality> format.

If you want to select from a range of skills, you can specify multiple skills like this:

[admin|diplomat|persuade+2]

This will randomly select one of admin, diplmat or persuade, and add +2 to it.

[STR-1]

Decrement characteristic by the given amount.

# Some text

Everything after a '#' is stripped from the text output, but added to the description field of the npcData. If some of this text is enclosed in {{ }} then it will be marked as secret in the NPC description, so players will not be able to see it.

Examples

See the following examples for profession

  • Scientist [age+2D6] [INT+1] [EDU+3] [science+2] [science+1] [admin|profession+0] # A scientist going to a conference. {{They are actually a spy}}

Adds 2D6 to the NPCs age, increments INT by 1 and EDU by 3, adds +2 to a random Science skill, and +1 to another random Science skill (they could both select the same skill), and either set admin or professiont to 0. Then adds "A scientist going to a conference" to the NPCs description. The text They are actually a spy will be included as a secret block, so won't be visible to players.

The only text put in the Profession field for the NPC would be "Scientist"
